pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.html:
I realise that this comment may be better suited to an issue rather than a pull request...

Is there any reason why Sensor::noises is of type std::vector<NoisePtr>, as it makes it rather difficult to manage multiple noise streams per sensor? For example, I had to use this->noises[x]->Apply(...); throughout the code, where x is the some integer ID referencing an ordered noise stream that I've pushed onto the data structure. Given that sensor plugins may wish to override the noise callbacks, would it not be simpler to use a std::map<int,NoisePtr> and declare an enum in each sensor header file containing the streams. For example:

namespace gazebo
{
  namespace sensors
  {
    /// \addtogroup gazebo_sensors
    /// \{

    enum GpsSensorNoise {PosLatNoiseMeters, PosLonNoiseMeters, PosAltNoiseMeters,
        VelLatNoiseMeters, VelLonNoiseMeters, VelAltNoiseMeters};

    /// \class GpsSensor GpsSensor.hh sensors/sensors.hh
    /// \brief GpsSensor to provide position measurement.
    class GAZEBO_VISIBLE GpsSensor: public Sensor
    {
        ...
    };
}

Then, from a plugin one can call something along the following lines:

parentSensor->GetNoise(PosLatNoiseMeters)->SetCustomNoiseCallback(boost::bind(&GpsPlugin::Perturb,this,i,_1));

And within the actual sensor code noise management becomes a little more intuitive, ie.

noises[PosLatNoiseMeters] = NoiseFactory::NewNoiseModel(
       posElem->GetElement("horizontal")->GetElement("noise"));

Not essential, but may be nice for developers :)

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.html: That's a good idea. Do you want to add those enums to this pull request?

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.raw:
Oh, I think I meant that the enum's were a good idea, but `std::map<int,NoisePtr>` is very close to a `std::vector<NoisePtr>` since they can both be indexed by an integer. The enums could still be used with a `vector`, using the [at operator](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/container/vector/at) to provide bounds checking.

How does it sound to revert to `std::vector<NoisePtr>` but provide the enums?
content.html:
Oh, I think I meant that the enum's were a good idea, but std::map<int,NoisePtr> is very close to a std::vector<NoisePtr> since they can both be indexed by an integer. The enums could still be used with a vector, using the at operator to provide bounds checking.

How does it sound to revert to std::vector<NoisePtr> but provide the enums?

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.raw: I believe that the issue is ```std::vector<NoisePtr>``` can only be indexed by an integer ```x``` if it has been allocated a minimum of ```x``` elements, whereas a ```std::map<int,NoisePtr>``` does not suffer the same problem. The resulting behaviour is that with a ```std::vector<NoisePtr>``` we'd still need a strictly-ordered sequence of ```std::vector::push_back(...)``` calls, unless we pre-allocated the correct vector size in the constructor.  Perhaps I'm unnecessarily worried about developers getting this wrong. Would you prefer ```push_back``` or pre-allocation?
content.html: I believe that the issue is std::vector<NoisePtr> can only be indexed by an integer x if it has been allocated a minimum of x elements, whereas a std::map<int,NoisePtr> does not suffer the same problem. The resulting behaviour is that with a std::vector<NoisePtr> we'd still need a strictly-ordered sequence of std::vector::push_back(...) calls, unless we pre-allocated the correct vector size in the constructor. Perhaps I'm unnecessarily worried about developers getting this wrong. Would you prefer push_back or pre-allocation?

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.raw: The `std::vector::push_back(...)` calls only need to happen once in `GpsSensor::Load`, so I'm fine with it. I'll see if @nkoenig has a preference.
content.html: The std::vector::push_back(...) calls only need to happen once in GpsSensor::Load, so I'm fine with it. I'll see if @nkoenig has a preference.

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.html:
It would be more explicit to have one enum for all noise types. Users would also be able to see all the different noise types in one doxygen location, rather than searching through each sensor. The enum could live in SensorTypes.hh. Something like:

enum SensorNoiseTypes
{
    /// \brief blah blah
    /// \sa CameraSensor
    CameraNoise = 0,

    /// \brief blah blah
    /// \sa GpsSensor
    VelLatNoiseMeters = 1,
}

Then the noise map in Sensor.hh would:

std::map<SensorNoiseType, NoisePtr> noises

Thoughts?

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.raw: I think that design sounds sensible, and I'd be happy to action it if @scpeters agrees.
content.html: I think that design sounds sensible, and I'd be happy to action it if @scpeters agrees.

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.html:
One last thing --- do we want to think about changing to the following to preserve backwards compatibility with any third party sensor plugins that used the old std::vector<NoisePtr> data structure?

/// \brief Noise streams for the Camera sensor
/// \sa CameraSensor
enum CameraSensorNoiseTypes
{
  CameraNoise = 0
};

/// \brief Noise streams for the GPU ray sensor
/// \sa GpuRaySensor
enum GpuRayNoiseTypes
{
  GpuRayNoise = 0
};

/// \brief Noise streams for the GPS sensor
/// \sa GpsSensor
enum GpsNoiseTypes
{
  GpsPositionLatitudeNoiseMeters = 0,
  GpsPositionLongitudeNoiseMeters = 1, 
  GpsPositionAltitudeNoiseMeters = 2,
  GpsVelocityLatitudeNoiseMeters = 3, 
  GpsVelocityLongitudeNoiseMeters = 4,
  GpsVelocityAltitudeNoiseMeters = 5
};

/// \brief Noise streams for the multicamera sensor
/// \sa MultiCameraSensor
enum MultiCameraNoiseTypes
{
  MultiCameraNoise = 0
};

/// \brief Noise streams for the ray sensor
/// \sa RaySensor
enum RaySensorNoiseTypes
{
  RayNoise = 0
};

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.raw:
I believe we can deprecate `NoisePtr GetNoise(unsigned int _index = 0) const` and implement `NoisePtr GetNoise(const SensorNoiseType _type) const` as a replacement. 

The only users who would be affected are people who may have directly used the `noises` vector, which should be fairly minimal.

The Migration guide should be updated to include this information.
content.html:
I believe we can deprecate NoisePtr GetNoise(unsigned int _index = 0) const and implement NoisePtr GetNoise(const SensorNoiseType _type) const as a replacement.

The only users who would be affected are people who may have directly used the noises vector, which should be fairly minimal.

The Migration guide should be updated to include this information.

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.raw: I have changed this back to an ```int``` to preserve compatibility with the ```MultiCamera``` sensor. As far as I can tell, this sensor can define an abritrary number of noise streams --- one for each camera. So, it is impossible to enumerate these cameras in advance. The ```enum SensorNoiseType``` type can be cast to an ```int``` easily, so I hope that this isn't an issue.
content.html: I have changed this back to an int to preserve compatibility with the MultiCamera sensor. As far as I can tell, this sensor can define an abritrary number of noise streams --- one for each camera. So, it is impossible to enumerate these cameras in advance. The enum SensorNoiseType type can be cast to an int easily, so I hope that this isn't an issue.

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.raw: That's fine. Thanks for looking into it.
content.html: That's fine. Thanks for looking into it.

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.raw: Are you happy with how I have changed this deprecated ```Sensor::GetNoise(unsigned int _index)``` to be compatible with the way in which noise streams are now managed by the ```Sensor``` class? I have essentially coded a sensor-specific mapping between the old integers and the new enums. The only exception is the ```MultiCameraSensor```, where I use the integer index directly.
content.html: Are you happy with how I have changed this deprecated Sensor::GetNoise(unsigned int _index) to be compatible with the way in which noise streams are now managed by the Sensor class? I have essentially coded a sensor-specific mapping between the old integers and the new enums. The only exception is the MultiCameraSensor, where I use the integer index directly.

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.raw: This now adds a noise model for each camera ```i``` at ```Sensor::noises[i]```.
content.html: This now adds a noise model for each camera i at Sensor::noises[i].

pullrequest.title: Switch to six independent GPS sensor noise models

content.html:
@nkoenig has already fixed them on default in 626fab4 and 1391be0

There is a script called code_check.sh in the tools folder that runs cppcheck and cpplint. It can be invoked from the root of the repository with sh tools/code_check.sh

It's kind of a slow script, so there are some tricks to make it run faster by only checking a subset of the files. For example, the tools/bitbucket_pullrequests -c 0 command can check the files modified by the most recent commit.
